name: How to share data via PGP Encryption.txt - What is PGP?
description: This section provides an overview of Pretty Good Privacy (PGP), which is a standard used for encrypting, decrypting, and digitally signing data. It explains that PGP was originally a proprietary standard but has become a de facto standard for secure email communication and verifying the identity of package repositories. The section also clarifies the difference between PGP, OpenPGP (an IETF standard), and GPG (GNU Privacy Guard, which is based on OpenPGP standards).

name: How to share data via PGP Encryption.txt - Why do we use PGP encryption?
description: This section is meant to explain the reasons and motivations behind using PGP (Pretty Good Privacy) encryption. PGP is a widely used encryption method that allows secure communication and data sharing between parties by encrypting the data in a way that only the intended recipient can decrypt and access it.
use_cases: Secure communication and data sharing between parties
Protecting sensitive or confidential information from unauthorized access
Enabling secure file transfers and email communication

name: How to share data via PGP Encryption.txt - How do we use it?
description: This section explains how to use GPG (GNU Privacy Guard) encryption to securely transmit or receive sensitive data, such as SFTP secrets or any confidential communication. It provides step-by-step instructions for importing public keys, listing keys in the keyring, encrypting files using a recipient's public key, generating a new private-public key pair, listing all keys, and exporting one's own public key.
use_cases: Transmitting or receiving SFTP secrets securely
Secure transmission of any confidential or clandestine communication
Encrypting files or data for specific recipients using their public keys
Generating and managing one's own private-public key pair for encryption and decryption
capabilities: Encrypting files using a recipient's public key
